The average for this time of the year is just 17C. Tomorrow a cold front will pass through, bringing an end to the 'summer-like' temperatures for now.

articles.title: There Goes Antarctica
articles.author: I Editorial Board
articles.summary: There was a record-breaking increase in the Antarctic Ice Sheet between 2021 and 2023. Four major glaciers in the Wilkes Land–Queen Mary Land region of East Antarctica reversed their previous pattern of accelerated mass loss from 2011 to 2020 and instead showed significant mass gain during the 2021 to 2023 period. The study points to anomalous precipitation as the primary driver, suggesting natural variability plays a significant role in ice sheet changes.

articles.title: City of Bunbury's fire pit ban branded 'silly' as cold weather hits
articles.author: Pip Waller
articles.summary: The City of Bunbury banned backyard fire pits at the end of last year. Residents on land of two hectares or less cannot use pits or have campfires any time of year. The ban came after a number of bushfires in the area. Gavin Pound tried to apply for a permit to have a fire pit going for his daughter's birthday party, but was told pit fires in Bunbury have been banned completely. The council is reconsidering the policy.

articles.title: Deadly mushrooms pop up in backyards after cool, wet weather prompting alert
articles.summary: Australians have been warned of deadly mushrooms popping up in backyards, parks and bushland as the weather gets cooler and wetter.    i.e. in the backyards and in bushland, because of the cooler weather and wet weather.

articles.title: NASA Reveals 'Higher Than Expected' Sea Level Rise in 2024
articles.author: Tessa Koumoundouros
articles.summary: In 2024, the sea level rise was 0.59 cm (0.23 in) higher than predicted by NASA oceanographer Josh Willis. This rise was caused by thermal expansion of liquid seawater, despite the loss of glacial ice. Warmer water is less dense, so it takes up more room than cold water. Earth's oceans are the warmest they've been in three decades of records.

articles.title: African Climate Platform demands justice, intergeneragional equity in global climate decision making
articles.author: Dennis Peprah
articles.summary: The African Climate Platform (ACP) has submitted a petition to the African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights calling for climate justice and intergenerational equity to guide both regional and global climate decision-making. The petition is backed by organizations including Resilient40, Natural Justice, the Environmental Lawyer Collective for Africa, and the Pan African Lawyers Union (PALU). Since April 27, 2025, environmental lawyers, climate advocates, Indigenous leaders, women's rights activists, and youth representatives from across the continent met in Arusha, Tanzania, to finalize the petition. It represents a united African response to the accelerating climate crisis.

articles.title: Australia and North America have long fought fires together – but new research reveals that has to change
articles.author: Andreia Filipa Silva Ribeiro
articles.summary: Climate change is lengthening fire seasons across much of the world. Australia and North America share firefighting resources. El Niño and La Niña play a role in the development of the fire seasons in both hemispheres. In the future, climate change will dominate the trend towards longer overlapping fire seasons.

articles.title: Heat on us
articles.author: SNS
articles.summary: India is heating faster than the global average, and its poorest are on the frontline of a crisis they did not cause. This year, large swathes of the country are likely to see record-breaking temperatures. The wealthy retreat to air-conditioned homes and offices, while the working class toils through blistering afternoons with little more than a scarf for protection. Public health must become central to climate policy.

articles.title: 'Spring dip' blamed for steep uptick in B.C. wildfires
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: The number of wildfires in B.C. has doubled over the past several days. Amanda Graves, an information officer with the Wildfire Service, says the increase is due to the annual 'spring dip' which is caused by a decrease in moisture in the needles of coniferous trees. Six of the 46 fires started in the last 24 hours were human-caused and 80 per cent were caused by humans.

articles.title: New Study: Australia, North America Must Rethink Fire Tactics
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Climate change is lengthening fire seasons across much of the world. There is an increase in the overlap of the fire seasons between Australia and North America. El Niño and La Niña may also play a role in this trend. Australia's fire weather season has lengthened at nearly twice the rate of western North America's.

articles.title: UN Special Rapporteur on Climate and Human Rights to visit Dominica
articles.author: Jovani Davis
articles.summary: Dr. Elisa Morgera, UN Special Rapporteur on the promotion and protection of human rights in the context of climate change, will visit Dominica from May 7 to 14, 2025. Her mission is to assess how climate change is affecting Dominicans' human rights. Dominica has positioned itself as the world's first climate-resilient nation following the devastation of Hurricane Maria in 2017.

articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The number of wildfires in British Columbia has doubled over the past few days. The activity is due to the annual 'spring dip' caused by a decrease in moisture in the needles of coniferous trees. Six of the 46 fires started in the last 24 hours were human-caused. Last month, the wildfire service forecasted a warmer-than-usual spring and above-average precipitation for coastal and Central B.C.

articles.title: How a wildfire started near Redwater, Alta.
articles.summary: A wildfire has burned close to 400 hectares near Redwater, Alta., since Saturday. It started after an all-terrain vehicle caught fire at the Redwater Provincial Recreation Area. It's not the only wildfire burning in the province right now, Travis McEwan reports.

articles.summary: The Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) has shown signs of record-breaking growth after decades of contributing to global sea-level rise. A study published in Science China Earth Sciences revealed that between 2021 and 2023, the AIS gained mass at a rate of 108 gigatons per year.

articles.author: Human Rights Watch
articles.summary: A coalition of African lawyers and civil society groups has asked the African Court on Human and Peoples' Rights for an advisory opinion on 55 African Union member states' human rights duties in the climate emergency. Africa accounts for only a tiny fraction of the global emissions contributing to the climate crisis. The continent is acutely vulnerable to climate impacts, with communities on the front lines facing droughts, desertification, and floods.

No major changes are expected in how Australia engages with the Pacific, geopolitical experts say. Griffith will repair relations that they felt had been let slide.

articles.title: 2022 floods caused over $30bn losses, NA told
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: The Ministry of Climate Change and Environmental Coordination presented a report to the National Assembly about the losses suffered by Pakistan in the wake of climate change during the last three years. Since 2022, Pakistan has experienced substantial financial losses due to climate change, primarily from the devastating 2022 floods. The 2022 floods caused an estimated USD 30 billion in damages and economic losses. The agriculture, livestock, and fisheries sector suffered the highest damage, estimated at Rs. 429 billion (USD 5 billion). The floods have led to a surge in malaria and other waterborne diseases, causing a strain on the healthcare system. There was a severe drought in Sindh and a heatwave in May and June.

articles.title: Ice all but disappeared from St. Paul Island. It changed everything.
articles.author: Joshua Partlow
articles.summary: St. Paul island in the Bering Sea is experiencing climate change. Warming waters have wiped out many species of fish, birds and crabs on the island. The island's largest source of tax revenue, a crab processing plant, closed three years ago. The number of city employees dropped from 43 to 18, the police force disbanded, and prices rose at the island's lone grocery store.

The economic impact of future flood damage, insurance losses, and disaster recovery could strain both individual homeowners and the town's resources.
